newsitem.title: FRANCE: Europe grain firms question Russia's import plans.
newsitem.headline: Europe grain firms question Russia's import plans.

text.p: European grain traders on Tuesday threw doubt on Russia's ability to secure its grain import needs in 1997, but did not rule small purchases.
Exporters said they doubted cash-strapped Russia could finance a major import programme.
"They need to import grain but where are they going to find the cash," one exporter said.
Russian agriculture Minister Viktor Khlystun said earlier that Russia would import 4-5 million tonnes of grain in 1997, including 2.5 to three million tonnes of high quality wheat.
Traders said they had learned to be cautious when dealing with Russia.
Large grain purchases failed to materialise last season after Russia made similar announcements, they said.
"One can think it is just one more non-binding Russian announcement," another exporter said.
Traders explained that what made large-scale imports unlikely was the fact that the private sector and not the state would continue to do the buying.
Khlystun, reiterating Moscow's policy of the past three years, told a news conference the state would do no buying and any imports would be channelled through private firms.

Exporters said they doubted Russia -- whose harvest made a disappointing recovery in 1996 from last year's crop, the worst in a generation -- could generate enough cash from grain exports to help finance imports in other parts of the country.
Khlystun said Russia would export 6-7 million tonnes of grain from its 1996 harvest.
Khlystun put Russia's 1996 net grain output at 68.4 million tonnes, below government expectations of around 70 million and compared with last year's 63.4 million.
"I will believe it when they actually do some buying," one exporter said, referring to the planned imports.
But traders said they could not rule out small purchases by private operators.
They said Russian importers had already secured good-quality wheat from Argentina and Germany in recent months.
And Russian importers were seen likely to continue buying cheaper supplies in small quantities from Kazakhstan and Argentina.
Canadian, Australian and even European wheat stood a chance against high-priced U.S. wheat, traders said.
Russia was reported to have a harvest with relatively little high-quality wheat and needed to import wheat with a protein content of some 13.5-14 percent.
This would limit imports of wheat from the European Union which had an average protein content of 11 percent this year.
Record yields in parts of Europe produced a bumper crop but at the expense of protein levels needed for bread-making, especially in parts of France.
-- Paris newroom +331 4221 5432
